STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING DIRECTOR
August 10, 2021
Ellen Westgate
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
RE: License #: CB810201018
Investigation #: 2021C0207019
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
Dear Ms. Westgate:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat noncompliances, identify why the previous CAP was
unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB810201018
Investigation #: 2021C0207019
Complaint Receipt Date: 06/02/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 06/02/2021
Report Due Date: 08/09/2021
Licensee Name: Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw
Licensee Address: 4925 Packard Rd
Ann Arbor, MI 481081521
Licensee Telephone #: Unknown
Administrator: Ellen Westgate, Designee
Licensee Designee: Ellen Westgate, Designee
Name of Facility: Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
Facility Address: 4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
Facility Telephone #: (734) 971-9781
Original Issuance Date: 01/01/1992
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 02/08/2020
Expiration Date: 02/07/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency recommended revocation of the foster home license Yes
without justification.
Agency placed youth in licensed foster home that were contrary to Yes
preference documented on the 3706. When foster parent was
unable to care for the youth, license revocation was pursued. One
of the youths was eventually placed in a residential where they
have been restrained over 40 times.
III. METHODOLOGY
06/02/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0207019
06/02/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Letter
Emails exchanged with Disciplinary Action Unit (DAU) Manager
related to the recommendation for revocation. Documentation
provided for review and reference.
06/02/2021 Contact - Document Received
Complaint and facility information reviewed.
06/14/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Interview with complainant via phone.
06/14/2021 Contact - Document Received
MiSACWIS information reviewed.
08/06/2021 Contact - Document Received
MiSACWIS information reviewed.
08/09/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Chief Administrator/Licensing Supervisor.
08/09/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Reviewed findings in pre-exit discussion with Chief
Administrator/Licensing Supervisor.
08/09/2021 Contact - Document Received
MiSACWIS information reviewed.
2

ALLEGATION:
Agency recommended revocation of the foster home license without justification.
INVESTIGATION:
On 06/02/21, I received an email notification of this complaint indicating the following
had been reported to DCWL Area Manager 2,
I received a complaint from the complainant. She states that Catholic Social
Services placed kids with the foster parent contrary to what the foster parent put
as her preference on the 3706. When the foster parent was unable to care for
these kids, one of which had to be placed at (a residential facility) and had been
restrained 40 times, they eventually moved to revoke her license.
I interviewed the complainant via phone on 06/14/2021. The complainant reported
that she feels the agency placed several children in the foster home that did not fit
the placement specifications of the home, and when those children acted out, the
agency moved to revoke the license and blame the foster parent. The complainant
identified Foster Child A, Foster Child B, Foster Child C, Foster Child D, and Foster
Child E. The complainant said the children were autistic, assaultive, and some of
them had eating disorders, walked out of the house, and defecated on the floor. The
complainant also reported that some of the youth were bedwetters and noted that
the foster parent did not take bedwetters. The complainant said that the placing
workers for Foster Children A and B minimized the kids’ behaviors to get them
placed. The complainant said the worker (the Chief Administrator) for Foster
Children C, D, and E (a sibling group) did not disclose all of the kids’ behaviors at
the disclosure meeting. The complainant said that the Chief Administrator was
present at the meeting with the placing workers from another agency. It was then
clarified that Foster Child A and Foster Child B were placed as borrowed bed
placements through another agency and not by Catholic Social Services of
Washtenaw. The complainant alleged the one of the workers from the other agency
told the kids to make complaints against the foster parent and that the foster parent
caught the worker in lies when the foster parent recorded conversations. The
complainant reportedly felt that the foster parent would not have had these problems
if the agency did not put children in the home that were outside the placement
specifications. The complainant noted that the foster parent wants to move her
license to another agency.
MiSACWIS case information was reviewed for the foster home license as well as the
children named in the complaint. The foster home placement specifications indicated
that the foster parent would not take youth who smeared stool, were delinquent,
autistic, encopretic, were sexually aggressive, or were LGBTQ. Placement
specifications that were permitted were bedwetting, mental health diagnosis, ADHD,
special education, emotionally disturbed/impaired, and cross racial. These
placement parameters were noted on the 2019 and 2020 CWL 3080 CHILDREN’S
FOSTER HOME RULES COMPLIANCE RECORD. The 2019 CWL 3080 was
3

signed by the foster parent. The 2020 CWL 3080 was electronically signed due to
COVID. It was also confirmed, via MiSACWIS case reviews, that Foster Child A and
Foster Child B were placed by another agency as borrowed bed placements. I
reviewed case history information for both Foster Child A and Foster Child B and
found neither to have a diagnosis of autism noted in MiSACWIS. I reviewed case
history information for Foster Children C, D, and E. They were placed by the agency.
Only Foster Child C was found to have a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder, but
at the time of placement in the foster parent’s home, it was only found on his
Individualized Education Plans, dating back to 12/06/18. The most recent Case
Service Plan (04/12/21-07/9/21) notes that the child has ADHD and is on the autism
spectrum. There was no diagnosis of autism for Foster Child D or E in the historical
information or in the most recent Case Service Plan. Social work contacts were
reviewed and did not document any disclosure of autism for any of the named
children. One provider contact, dated 07/23/20, entered by the Chief Administrator,
noted that the kids (Foster Children C, D, and E) still needed trauma assessments,
the behaviors reported by the foster parent were not reported in previous
placements, and identified that one of the children was encopretic and smearing
stool.
The Chief Administrator (CA), who was also responsible for the direct case at the
time of services, reported phone interview and via follow up emails that the children
did not have any behaviors prior to their placement in the foster parent’s home. The
CA acknowledged that Foster Child C had an IEP for Autism, but it was only from
the IEP and not a formal mental health diagnosis. The CA said he fidgets a great
deal but other than that, the children were good children. The CA said that in the full
disclosure meeting for adoption, the foster parent was advised of this and many of
the workers and supervisors asked the foster parent if she would be okay parenting
three to four additional children. Per the CA, the foster parent indicated that she
would be fine. The CA reported that it wasn’t until after the children were placed in
her home, that the foster parent started calling the staff related to the kids’
behaviors. The CA said that the foster parent complained that the children were
eating all the time and Foster Child E was giving her problems. As time went on, the
foster parent continued to call workers and asked for removal of the children, but
later said Foster Child E could stay. The agency removed Foster Child C and Foster
Child D while Foster Child E remained until they found a home for all three of the
children. The CA said that MCI was consulted on this case and a case conference
call took place as well. MCI reportedly gave permission to split Foster Child C and
his two siblings until the agency could find a home for all three. The CA also
reported that she felt the problem was that as time went on in the foster home, the
foster parent indicated that the children were having all these behaviors. When the
increased difficulty of care rate was denied, the foster parent then asked for their
removal. The CA reported that since the children have been out of the foster
parent’s home, they all are doing very well. Most all of the issues that were brought
to their attention by the foster parent have not been present in their new foster
home. The CA forwarded some emails related to setting up the full disclosure
4

meeting, one of which showed that she sent the IEP to the foster parent. This was
not sent to the foster parent until 07/07/20, which was one week after placement.
The agency was previously investigated for their special evaluation work related to
this foster home in Special Investigation Report (SIR) 2021C0207012. The agency
was cited in this investigation for R 327 Special Evaluation, as they did not
document a thorough investigation of the allegations. They combined multiple intake
allegations, some received three weeks apart, into one report and did not clearly
identify all the allegations and when they were received. Additionally, the findings
and conclusions were not supported by documented facts and information, as the
agency failed to include the worker’s analysis of gathered information, or
descriptions of findings, observations and supporting documentation. The SIR had
other violations noted for the facility, but also found that the foster parent had three
adults move into the home prior to obtaining clearances, one of whom had a criminal
history. The foster parent also allowed one of the adults to share a bedroom with
one of the current foster children and to provide care and supervision of the child
due to the child’s aggression.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Foster Parent licensing information in MiSACWIS
 Foster Children A, B, C, D, and E-applicable case information reviewed in
MiSACWIS
 Special Investigation Report 2021C0207012
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained
in the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the rule as the special evaluation
reports used for the revocation were not completed per licensing
rules and lacked content.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Report, 02/10/20, CAP 02/21/20
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(5) An agency shall recommend to the department the
denial of license issuance, the revocation of a license, or
the refusal to renew a license only when both of the
following conditions exist:
(a) The applicant or the foster parent falsifies
information or, the applicant or the foster parent
willfully and substantially violates the act, 1or more
of the licensing rules for foster homes, or the terms
of the license.
(b) The applicant or the foster parent has been informed,
in writing, of the facts and the basis for the
recommended action.
ANALYSIS: Evidence in the record and discovered in SIR 2021C0207012
shows the foster parent to be willfully and substantially
noncompliant with licensing rules.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Agency placed youth in licensed foster home that were contrary to preference
documented on the 3706. When foster parent was unable to care for the youth,
license revocation was pursued. One of the youths was eventually placed in a
residential where they have been restrained over 40 times.
INVESTIGATION:
See investigation notes above.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(3) An agency's placement of a child in a foster home shall
be consistent with the placement specifications for the
home.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the rule, as Foster Child C’s record
shows that he was receiving special education services via his
Individualized Education Plan, for having an Autism Spectrum
Disorder, which was not an acceptable specification of the foster
home license. Even though the agency reported that the foster
parent was told of this, there was no documentation in the
record to show that the foster parent was provided this
information prior to placement. Other behaviors the complainant
reported to be outside of the foster parent’s specifications were
either found to be listed as acceptable, or not noted in the case
history until after being placed in the foster home.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings in this report, I recommend no change to the current license
status. This recommendation is contingent on the agency submitting an acceptable
corrective action plan for the noted violations.
August 09, 2021
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 10, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
7
